article.headline: Google searches for K-shaped recovery, white supremacy and âhow to move to New Zealandâ spiked during the debate
article.body: The first presidential debate between Donald Trump and Joe Biden may have raised more questions than it answered. While the political opponents battled over the government response to the coronavirus pandemic, economic recovery and civil unrest across the country â often talking over each other and steamrolling over moderator Chris Wallace in the process â viewers turned to search engines like Google GOOG, +1.97% and dictionary sites like Merriam-Webster to help decipher what the candidates were saying. During the first hour of the roughly 90-minute debate, Googleâs top trending searches were: 1. K-shaped recovery 2. Roe v. Wade 3. How many people have pre existing conditions? 4. Who is winning the debate? 5. Affordable Care Act These correlated with the candidates arguing over whether weâll see a V-shaped (Trump) or K-shaped (Biden) economic recovery, as well as Trump nominating conservative Amy Coney Barrett for Ruth Bader Ginsburgâs vacant Supreme Court seat, and concerns that she could overturn Roe v. Wade, the landmark decision that legalized abortion. Opinion:Â About that K-shaped recovery: For half of America, the economy is still terrible Trump and Biden also sparred over health care, with Biden accusing Trump of cutting coverage for â100 million people who have pre-existing conditionsâ in the presidentâs attempts to scrap the Obama-era Affordable Care Act. Trump countered that, âThere arenât 100 million people with pre-existing conditions.â The real number depends upon whom you ask: The Kaiser Family Foundation estimated that at least 53.8 million adults had pre-existing conditions in 2018, but a 2017 Department of Health and Human Services studyÂ estimatedÂ that 133 million people had pre-existing conditions that would make them unable to buy insurance. Read more:Hereâs where Trump and Biden stand on health care Search interest for âwhite supremacyâ also surged during the debate, after Wallace asked Trump to condemn white supremacists and militia groups, and to tell them to stand down and not add to the violence in cities that have been rocked by protests against racial injustice and police brutality. The presidentâs response left many critics concerned. He told the Proud Boys, a far-right group that the Southern Poverty Law Center has classified as a hate group, and that has been suspended by Twitter TWTR, -0.23% Â and Facebook FB, +0.26%, to âstand back and stand by.â He then added, âBut Iâll tell you what, somebodyâs got to do something about antifa and the left.â iframe.twitter-tweet { width: 100% !important; } This exchange led the top trending-related search, âTrumpâs response to white supremacy,â to spike more than +5,000%, Google reported. That subject struck a nerve with a lot of viewers, as âProud Boysâ was the top Twitter trend on Wednesday morning, and âTrumpâ and âwhite supremacyâ also dominated Google trends early in the day. The New York Times reported that the Proud Boys themselves were calling Trumpâs comments âhistoric,â and that in one channel dedicated to the Proud Boys on the private messaging app Telegram, members considered the presidentâs words a âtacit endorsement of their violent tactics.â iframe.twitter-tweet { width: 100% !important; } Merriam-Webster tracked dictionary lookups during and after the debate, as well, finding that the most searched words included âwhite supremacist,â âantifa,â âpetulant,â âracism,â âpoll watcher,â âmoderatorâ and âstandby,â which could all be traced back to Trump and Bidenâs heated exchanges on Tuesday night. iframe.twitter-tweet { width: 100% !important; } Dictionary.com also picked up on CNNâs Dana Bash calling the debate a âshâshow,â clarifying that the crude phrase is one word, and saying that searches for it suddenly spiked on Tuesday night. iframe.twitter-tweet { width: 100% !important; } Whatâs more, U.S. Google searches for âhow to move to New Zealandâ also skyrocketed during the debate, according to Google Trends and reported by Newshub, a New Zealand media company. People in the state of Oregon (home to Portland, which has been a hotbed of protests against injustice) googled âhow to move to New Zealandâ the most, while residents in Washington, Nevada and UtahÂ were also especially interested, according to the data. Related:Hereâs how you can get foreign citizenship and a second passport in as little as two years Read MarketWatchâs debate analysis here, and track our 2020 election coverage here.
